reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you want to pay $20 for an unfinished game that looks like it belongs on Dreamcast, here's your chance. Don't get me wrong, I'm not a big graphics guy. I can easily dig a good game with retro style graphics like Shovel Knight that pays good homage to its era. In comparison, TBC just looks dated (gaming circa 2002) and has probably the ugliest use of cel shading I've ever seen. The game's atmosphere feels sterile void of any charm or interest. And the audio? Completely forgettable, I don't remember a single tune from the game, granted most of the playtime is with the Desura build so this may have changed with the Steam release but from my brief testing, the game appears unchanged from its most recent build on Desura.

The gameplay isn't much better. The controls are ultra clunky and the combat reminds me slightly of the old PS2/XBox horror game Cold Fear but have action games come a long way since then and honestly Cold Fear already did it better. The puzzles are easy and occasionally well crafted but don't feel substantial enough to carry the game. It feels like the game was trying to be a mix of something cerebral like Portal and while having action similar to Resident Evil 4 but fell completely flat in both regards.   If a developer is going to price their game at the level of some of the 2 year old AAA games, it should be able to hold its own. No, I'm not expecting AAA quality from an indie developer, but the pricing falls in the premium range as far as indie products go therfore I expect something good. This game is far from the indie cream of the crop. TBC fails miserably in many areas and it's simply just not fun to play.

I'm glad I won my copy in the winter auction for far less than the regular price. At regular price, the game is far too boring and unpolished to be worth the $$$. There's some honest hard effort evident in this game but good effort is not enough reason to give a recommendation. At least, the game seems to launch more stable in its Steam release, I had to jump through hoops to get the game to simply load through Desura. In comparison I tried loading the game 3 times in Steam and it loaded perfectly each time.

I could comment of the developers' behavior regarding bundle buyers but I won't delve too much into that area. I will say this: the gaming consumer base does not take kindly to censorship. The developers will have to learn how to better handle criticism of their product or for any of the choices they make. Deleting comments and censoring the issue simply doesn't help or resolve anything. I'm not one of the people who expect a Steam key from Desura games so this incident did not affect my choice in not recommending this game. I solely judged the game on its merits (or lack thereof) to give my rating.

Keep in mind this is an Early Access game, things could improve in the future and if they do improve I will be willing to re-visit the game and change my recommendation if the game warrants it. As it remains now, the game is a mess and not one I can recommend.

Early Access Review

This game touts itself as being a metroidvania 3D game but honestly it has nothing of the genre. It's a 3D, character changer puzzler with shooter elements. Think 3rd person Gobliiins with guns.

I have a limited amount of playtime on Steam, but keep it mind I had the game on Desura from my previous purchase and had played it before.

The game is still in early alpha and it shows, very much. Controls and movements are sluggish, graphics are very bland and sterile (the washed out cell shading effect doesn't do it for me), and in my case the game wouldn't even start without completely deactivating audio. The default controls aren't well thought of either and you will find yourself frustratingly deactivating panels while trying to change character. You are thrown into the game with no real explanation but a few engrish lines of text as you go on, teaching you the bare minimum. The atmosphere felt dull, and I got no real entertainment factor. There's a reason no one is playing the game, including those who provided such good reviews.

I understand that the game is currently in Early Access, actually it has been in alpha state for nearly 3 years, and I'd be happy to revisit this review if I'm told that any significant improvement has been made regarding these issues.

There's also the fact that communications between the developers and the community has been less than stellar, their choice of providing only a subset of their previous customers with a Steam copy of the game they bought, and deleting negative comments on both Steam's community hub and the Desura game page. (Some of those comments were downright nasty but there was also legitimate criticism that got deleted.)

Early Access Review

I'm writing this review because the devs asked me to.

Pros
- challenging puzzles (I especially enjoyed the waterfall mechanic!)
- solid story background (It's not an RPG)
- can run on a potato. I tried running it on my really bad 2gb netbook and I was able to get a solid 30fps.
- can run on a gaming rig and still look half-decent. Cel-shaded art doesn't need to look super detailed.

Cons
- clunky combat. I'd prefer to dodge-roll with Q or E. Double-tapping A and D in the middle of a fight is really tricky!
- The first level requires you to do some MAJOR backtracking to pick up an item. Literally; most of my time in this game was spent trying to figure this out.
- clunky Synb/item switching switching system. I feel an action wheel would work better than opening up a separate UI.
- You can switch to a Synb in a different level. This is really cool, but I haven't seen the feature used in-game at all. I think it would be cool if you had to use a Synb stuck in another level to activate a switch to progress. (This may be me being an idiot, but what do I know? ¬Ø\_(„ÉÑ)_/¬Ø
- ALL OF THE ACHIEVEMENT NAMES ARE IN ALLCAPS. I DON'T UNDERSTAND WHY.
- Personally, I feel that a top-down view with RTS-style controls would work really well for this game. It would certainly make the game easier to play without taking away from the challenge.

Conclusion

This game is definitely in its' early stages of development and absolutely needs more polish. In its' current state, it's definitely not worth $20. However, the game's concept is definitely there. When I finally finished the first level, I was on top of the world. I wish the devs the best in making their dream game!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Body Changer is a genuinely intriguing blend of genres: at its core, it's a third person puzzle metroidvania game. But then it also splashes in some tense action gameplay alongside for you to experiment with (and these scenes are pretty tense). The challenges get progressively harder as you complete the objectives, and you get to tinker about with more guns & gadgets as well. And that's before we get onto the fantastic 'body-switching' mechanic - which adds that extra bit of ingenuity to make it a really fun game.

It also provides a solid return to the metroidvania genre* (see below). Expect to be racking your brains to figure out the puzzles, going back on yourself, finding objects which you just can't quite lay your hands on ;)

Also worth mentioning is the backdrop story and notably the art-style, which help provide an authentic, other-worldy (and eerie) atmopshere.

So it has a lot of potential, and with its open-minded devs, hopefully the ideas streaming in from players should be realised to a great standard. I am not trying to over-hype this game (which is a bad thing!), but it really does show a lot of promise, and does a lot of things well.

The Good:
+ Original blend of mechanics. Puzzle, action, themes from survival horror even. All encompassed by its evident dedication to the metroidvania genre.
+ Brilliant 'body-switching' mechanic. A lot of realised potential for this.. but there's more that's waiting to be explored with this I'm sure ;)
+ Great devs (only two of them as well!). They have a growing workload, yet they still remain in constant contact with their players. In my personal experience, they have only ever listened and acted on my feedback.
(Not directly to do with the game content, but hopefully should turn the faces of anyone put off by the 'Early Access' label)
+ Art-style is subjective to opinion (we might see some discussions arise in its Early Access stage), but I think it suits very well.
+ Weirdly eerie. Atmospheric and even frightening at the right times (there's that survival horror coming in!).. Decent SFX
+ Challenging puzzles & sticks true to metroidvania genre. You work out the puzzle (yes, it might be difficult!), and be prepared to go back on yourself a few times (a key mechanic of the metroidvania genre)

The Bad:
- Slightly clunky combat mechanics. These I'm sure will get a lot attention though.
- Environments could be a bit more .. pretty. In its current state. Minimalist world does suit though (complements the cel-shaded art-style).
- Some game progression bugs.
- UI needs a lot of work.
- Some QA (Quality Assurance) issues (relatively minor stuff though).
- Game could be longer (with more varied puzzles/combat sequences)... although it is by no means unimpressive at its current completion time (devs have said they are working on adding more levels).
- *EDIT: In my view, I would call this a solid metroidvania title.. however having read other reviews, some might think it doesn't do enough to earn that title. The game is likely to evolve more though to suit that genre if you felt it doesn't quite cut it.
- EDIT: Price. I would have imagined this as more of a below ¬£10 (approx. $15) range title.

All in all though, this for me has been one of the most interesting games I've played for a while. Its setup very well by this original blend of mechanics, as well as reintroducing a dedicated and fitting return to the metroidvania genre.

The devs are great too - and rest assured you will be listened to! (Of course they are also very busy - but they have shown nothing but passion to deliver on this project!)

And yes.. I have temporarily renamed my display name in respect to the devs and the game :)

EDIT: So having looked back at this review (and also after getting some downvotes), I hope I haven't over-hyped the game and made it seem like something more than it is (in its current state). I do have a lot passion for this game, and I genuinely believe it will be something great -- but some people might not be satisfied with, for example, the 'metroidvania' stamp, or the actual innovation behind the mechanics.

I stand by what I've said - because the bottom-line is I do love the game, and I have faith in the devs - but I can understand if people feel it's not cutting it for them. Of course - it is still Early Access, and definitely only *half-finished* at the moment. The devs have stated that they are working on adding more (interesting) levels, and I think there hasn't been a game like this on the market for a little while, at least not presented like The Body Changer has.

Thanks for reading anyway :)
